This dilution guide does one thing:

 1. It will allow you to enter a dilution factor and a final volume and calculate how much of the sample and diluent you need to add to achieve the desired dilution.

 This assumes all values are in the same units.

How to make a basic standard solution:

 This guide assumes all values are in the same units. By default Element lists standard concentrations in uL/mL or ppm.


1. Start with a clean container. Make sure to use a volumetric flask when more sensitive measurements are required.

 2. Add an initial amount of DI to the container, the exact amount is not important but make sure to leave enough room for the acids and standards you will need to add.

 3. Add the preservative, typically 2% nitric acid, and 1% hydrochloric acid by volume but this can vary depending on the standard being made.

 4. Add the standard to the container, make sure to use a pipette or other measuring device to ensure the correct amount is added.

 5. Bring the solution up to the final volume with DI water. If using a volumetric flask, make sure to mix the solution by inverting the flask several times and then decant the solution into a clean container.
